ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned an introduction to calc 1 and its application to real life scenarios.
How to do calculus

I feel like this course mostly refreshed my knowledge of calculus that I learned with IB Math: Analysis and Approaches at the Standard Level. A few things (Euler's method, Newton's method, differential equations, etc.) were foreign concepts, so it was nice to be able to interact with new material as well.
General introduction to calculus skills.
I learned about ways to differentiate an equation, and apply these skills to real life problems.
I learned how to absorb lots of information at a very quick pace.
Develop skills such as logical thinking and gain insight into calculus.
I think this course helped me understand the content more than just memorizing how to do certain problems like I did in high school.
I learned the fundamentals of derivatives and integrals.

I took away fundamental skills and knowledge of Calculus I, especially knowledge around derivatives and integrals. I learned how to apply the concepts I learned towards problems on my problem sets and tests. Derivatives and Integrals were the main two skills I took away.
I developed a better understanding of. the foundations of calculus
I learned a lot about the basic concepts of calculus.
I was able to strengthen my understanding of calculus and improve my problem solving skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is not well taught. There are some great instructors, such as Professor Geiger, but the material is not presented in an intuitive or engaging way. If I had not taken Calculus before I am not confident I would have been able to pass the course. Thankfully, the main problem of the course would be easy to fix, if the course were given using the "flipped" classroom model. Under this model, instructors would record lectures online and assign them as homework along with the Problem Sets. Then, class time would be used specifically for addressing student questions about the material and problem sets.
This course could be more engaging in class aside from just lecture notes and doing problems individually.

Strengths: worksheets handed out at the beginning of class
Weakness: pacing can feel fast sometimes

Sections, especially with Eric, were great! I wouldn't say I liked how the grading for Problem Sets wasn't centralized. For some PSets, points were taken off for ridiculous things (e.g., not simplifying answers when we were told that simplification wasn't required). I had to email Eric to make sure those points weren't lost which was definitely a hassle. This course was good overall, though! It wasn't draining like some of the other classes I was taking this semester.
Strength : good class notes weakness: need more in class questions
The classes sometimes were not as efficient as they possibly could have been. Other than that, I thought the course was good.

Strengths, alot of help to resources available to students. 

Weaknesses, could have more review sessions.
I wouldn't say that there was any main weaknesses everything ran pretty smoothly. I would like to say that Professor Eric was very supportive and helpful the whole semester.
I liked the guided notes! They were very helpful for me.

The strength was that the professor was accessible in answering questions or clarifying. I think the pace of the class was manageable as well. However, at many times, the problem sets contained questions that weren't completely covered in class. Additionally, the due dates of certain problem sets were extremely stressful (for example, there was a problem set that was due the night before our second midterm on topics that weren't relevant for that midterm; this problem set in particular was a lengthly and difficult one, and as a result, I did not have much time to study for the midterm, leaving me to perform poorly).

This course works very well when the graduate student teaching the section is engaged. Mr Geiger was very engaged, and I really appreciated that. However I can imagine that, without such a switched on teacher, the class could have been a lot more difficult to get through.
This course did a great job of providing students with resources to help them practice the concepts and skills that they were learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not really. Unless you are pursuing math or a degree requirement, I would stay away from this class. The material was presented in a confusing way under Geiger, and it was hard to learn in a lecture setting. Problem sets were unnecessarily hard given the subpar lessons in class, and more could've been learned under the various calculus teachers on Youtube.
No. Personally, even though I attended every class, I still ended up having to teach myself most of the material.
No
I would recommend this course to any student wishing to take a calc course that is more relaxed than the content and applications of 115 or higher.
If it is wasnt  necessary for my prospective major I wouldnt take it.

If you have to take a Calculus class for a major/degree requirement, I would say Calculus I is not a bad choice at all. If you're looking for a QR credit, you might want to look for other, more "gutty," classes because you do have to put in time and effort into the class if you want to do well. Eric was really awesome though. If you are going to take Calculus I, take it with Eric's section!
Yes
I would recommend this course to anyone who needs a fast paced introduction to calculus.
I would certainly recommend this course to someone interested in math or possibly a STEM major.
Yes. If you are interested in working with math I do recommend this course. It helps you think logically.

I would recommend this course to first year students over taking 110/111 because while it sounds like it might be a little difficult it is very doable. I had no trouble understanding and getting everything done.
Yes. This class is essential for understanding the basics of calculus.

I would recommend this course if the student needs it for a certain requirement, whether that's their QR requirement, major requirement, or requirement for graduate school. This course, I don't think, was too applicable to my long-term goals and was unnecessarily stressful (especially with the lengthly problem sets).
Yes. I think that this course sets students up well to be successful in other classes.
